entry.title: Housing stock summary
entry.content:
The English housing survey tables supplement information provided in the reports. Tables may also contain data from the former survey of English housing and the English house condition survey, providing information on change over time.

In some instances cells in the tables are based on a small number of cases and should be approached with caution. It may be necessary to add cells across categories before certain data can be used in a meaningful way. Full details of the way in which the survey was conducted, including details of the sample structure, and survey error and its calculation for specific sub-groups, are provided in English housing survey: technical advice.

Some tables, where indicated, are based on data from other surveys such as the Office for National Statistics labour force survey. Users should note that there may be slight differences in the household estimates produced using different data sources and methodologies.

entry.title: Building regulations Part P: electrical safety in dwellings
entry.content:
This final impact assessment sets out the proposed changes to Part P of the building regulations and provides an analysis of the associated costs and benefits.

The proposals aim to reduce the bureaucracy and cost burdens that Part P imposes on installers, building control bodies and consumers, without undermining the improvements to electrical safety, installer competence and the quality of electrical installation work arising from the introduction of Part P in 2005.

This impact assessment updates the consultation impact assessment which was a supporting document for Section 3 of the 2012 Building Regulations consultation.

entry.title: Triennial review of the Industrial Development Advisory Board (IDAB)
entry.content:
The Cabinet Office requires Non-Departmental Public Bodies (NDPBs) to be reviewed every 3 years by their parent department.

This review looks at the function of the Industrial Development Advisory Board (IDAB), the appropriateness of the bodyâ€™s delivery mechanisms and its governance arrangements.

It also describes the purpose of triennial reviews, the process adopted for this review and presents findings based on feedback from stakeholders. It draws on these findings to make recommendations about the future of IDAB.

entry.content:

entry.title: Recast of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive
entry.content:
The Energy Performance of Buildings Directive is an EU measure designed to tackle climate change by reducing the amount of carbon produced by buildings. The requirements of the Directive were implemented on a phased basis by the Energy Performance of Buildings (Certificates and Inspections) (England and Wales) Regulations 2007.

Key requirements were:

  • energy performance certificate to be produced on the sale, rent or construction of a building
  • display energy certificate to be produced and displayed in large public buildings
  • air conditioning equipment above a certain size to be inspected regularly

Changes have been made to the regulations, to transpose the requirements of a recast of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive in England and Wales. The main requirements will be introduced on 9 January 2013 and are summarised below:

  • property advertisements to include details of energy performance certificate rating where available
  • no longer a requirement to attach front page of the energy performance certificate to written material
  • extension of current requirement for a display energy certificate in large public buildings, to public buildings above 500mÂ². Unlike buildings larger than 1,000mÂ², display energy certificates for smaller public buildings will be valid for 10 years
  • energy performance certificate to be displayed in commercial premises larger than 500mÂ² where one has been previously issued

The guidance documents have been revised to reflect the changes and can be viewed via the links above.

The new regulations consolidate all existing regulations which have been revoked. They are available at legislation.gov.uk.

entry.title: Simplifying the provisions of Part B2 of the building regulations
entry.content:
This final impact assessment sets out the proposed changes to the provisions of requirement B2 of the building regulations relating to internal fire spread (linings).

These changes are intended to reduce the burden of these provisions on thermoplastic lighting diffusers and decorative wallcoverings whilst maintaining adequate levels of safety.

This impact assessment updates the consultation impact assessment which was a supporting document for Section 1 of the 2012 Building Regulations consultation.

entry.title: Civil Aviation Act: frequently asked questions
entry.content:
The document features frequently asked questions about the Civil Aviation Act.

The Act paves the way for the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to motivate airports to deliver better facilities, provide more information for passengers and give greater incentives for airports to prepare for disruptive events such as severe weather. The Act also makes provisions for future reforms to the Air Travel Organisersâ€™ Licensing (ATOL) scheme, which offers financial protection for holiday makers in the event of their tour operator going bust.

entry.title: UK National Strategy on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict
entry.content:
In March 2010 the United Kingdom launched a national strategy on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict (PoC). The strategy, a collaboration between the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, the Department for International Development and the Ministry of Defence, sets out what the Government is doing to keep the Protection of Civilians at the forefront of our work on political, security and humanitarian fronts. The strategy covers the period 2010-2013, and provides for annual progress reports.

This 2012 report summarises the UKâ€™s work in four policy areas:

  • Political engagement
  • Protection by peace support operations
  • Humanitarian action
  • State capacity

entry.content:
The Department for Communities and Local Government commissioned EC Harris to provide economic and analytical information to support evaluation work being carried out by the department on changes to the building regulations due to come into force in 2013.

entry.title: Business rates retention and the local government finance settlement: a practitioners guide
entry.content:
This guide provides an overview of the calculations set out in the local government finance settlement report 2013 to 2014 and the draft local government finance settlement report 2014 to 2015. It sets out how the business rates retention scheme has been set up and how it will operate.

This guide is aimed at local authority practitioners and is intended to be read alongside both local government finance reports and supporting documents which can be found on the local government finance settlement 2013 to 2014 website.

A glossary explaining the terminology used in the reports and in this document can be found at annex A.
